section2.p: Channel metadata is stored as node metadata against the /posts node of the channel. It is recommended that all channel nodes have the same permissions and an update to one updates the others.
Most metadata fields used for Channels are already defined in xep0060;. The relevant ones are listed below.

tr.td: Should be a brief single sentence
"This is a channel about the things that I like to do."
A longer description of the channel
The role given to new channel followers
The type of this channel. (see below). Set by the server at creation. Not user changable.
When the channel was created in ISO 8601 time format. Set by the server at creation. Not user changeable.
The date the channel configuration was later updated in ISO 8601 time format. Set by the server. Not user changable.
The type of content held within this node.

section2.p: Channel owners and moderators can also set the default affiliation for the channel

tr.td: Channel named after and owned by the user's JID.
A channel features around a common topic.

td.p: Appears as an open channel to local users on that domain.
Appears as a closed channel to users on remote Buddycloud domains.

tr.td: The channel is only viewable by it's producer, followers, followers+post and moderators.

td.p: Appears as an open channel to local users on that domain.
Appears as a closed channel to users on remote Buddycloud domains.

section2.p: Buddycloud is designed to be extended with new node and content types. To kickstart Buddycloud starts with some well known and used nodes. It is recommended that new nodes are announced publicly on the XSF standards mailing list and an informal registry will be kept.

tr.td: Key is published using ASCII Armour encoding scheme as detailed in RFC-2440, Section 6 and is encoded using the http://xmpp.org/extensions/xep-0189.xml#schema-pubkey syntax.
Applications use the Public Key to encode messages and posts to the node owner.
Describes where the channel owner was previously.
Describes where the channel owner is now.
Describe where the channel owner plans to go.

Show's an intended location or description (for example "Juliet's Balcony" or "Going out this evening to read love poetry"). A good application will clear the geoloc-future location when it matches the current location.
A one line descrition of the channels status.
For example a user might enter "Is happy" and a topic channel for a development team might have a status line of "Code is building correctly"
